title: 114_hr1559
content: The Act titled "Health Outcomes, Planning, and Education (HOPE) for Alzheimer's Act of 2015" aims to address health outcomes related to Alzheimer's disease. The "Health Outcomes, Planning, and Education (HOPE) for Alzheimer's Act of 2015" highlights the importance of early diagnosis and access to care planning services for individuals with Alzheimer's disease and other dementias. Congress emphasizes the need for comprehensive care planning services to improve outcomes for patients and their caregivers. The "Health Outcomes, Planning, and Education (HOPE) for Alzheimer's Act of 2015" aims to provide better care and outcomes for Medicare beneficiaries with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias by offering comprehensive care planning services. This includes reducing complications, costly emergency room visits, and hospitalizations, as well as allowing access to medical and non-medical treatments, building a care team, participating in support services, and enrolling in clinical trials. The Act provides care planning services for Medicare beneficiaries with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias, based on documented diagnosis in medical records. The Act amends Section 1861 of the Social Security Act to include Medicare coverage for comprehensive Alzheimer's disease care planning services. The Act includes Medicare coverage for comprehensive Alzheimer's disease care planning services provided by physicians or non-physician practitioners to eligible individuals, their personal representatives, and family caregivers. The Secretary will establish guidelines for these services. The Act includes Medicare coverage for comprehensive Alzheimer's disease care planning services provided to eligible individuals, including assistance with understanding diagnosis, treatment options, and obtaining necessary services. The services also involve considering the individual's other chronic conditions and comprehensive medical record documentation. The Secretary will periodically update requirements to reflect advances in science and technology. Comprehensive Alzheimer's disease care planning services can only be provided once per eligible individual. Initial care plans can be updated under other covered physician services. The Secretary will consult with stakeholders for input. The Secretary will consult with stakeholders, such as physicians and organizations representing individuals with Alzheimer's disease, regarding the scope of services and updates required. The term 'Alzheimer's disease' includes related dementias, and an 'eligible individual' must have a documented diagnosis after the enactment of this subsection. Payment for comprehensive Alzheimer's disease care planning is addressed in the amendment to Section 1833(a)(1) of the Social Security Act. The term 'Alzheimer's disease' encompasses related dementias, and an 'eligible individual' must have a documented diagnosis post-enactment of this subsection. The Secretary will collaborate with stakeholders, including physicians and organizations representing individuals with Alzheimer's disease, to determine the necessary services and updates. The amendment to the Social Security Act addresses payment for comprehensive Alzheimer's disease care planning services. Payment under the physician fee schedule and frequency limitations are also amended. The amendment to the Social Security Act expands coverage for comprehensive Alzheimer's disease care planning services under Medicare. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct outreach to educate physicians and practitioners about the changes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct outreach to inform physicians and practitioners about the addition of Alzheimer's disease care planning services as a covered benefit under Medicare, including diagnostic evaluations and eligibility requirements. A report on the outreach will be submitted to Congress within one year of the effective date of the amendments. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct outreach to inform physicians and practitioners about Alzheimer's disease care planning services covered under Medicare. A report on the outreach methods used will be submitted to Congress. Additionally, the Secretary will report annually on the number of Medicare beneficiaries receiving these services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will report annually on Medicare beneficiaries' access to Alzheimer's disease care planning services covered under Medicare, including any barriers faced and recommendations to eliminate them. The Secretary will also transmit a copy of the report to the Advisory Council on Alzheimer's Research, Care, and Services. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) will apply to services provided on or after January 1 following the enactment of this Act.
